biblFull.extent: "Includes 21 handwritten letters, 4 documents, and 1 CD-ROM. Letters written by William B. Anderson to his wife in Pennsylvania. He writes from his steamboat during the Civil War, as he ferries Union troops, ammunition and supplies up and down the river at Cincinnati and vicinity. Also contains documents showing his expenses and profits and a letter from another person. All letters are digitized and available on a CD, included in the collection" (OSU Libraries Catalog).

note.p: Selection of the Source Text. This edition contains the twenty letters written by William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa Anderson, taking a literal rather than figurative clue from what Anderson calls in one letter the "distres [sic] that this war has brought on the human family." By contrast, the additional letter in the collection and the four receipts deal exclusively with Anderson's shipping business.

In some ways, William B. Anderson's short letter of 27 June 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa, typifies the twenty-one letters from William to Louisa that survive in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. It addresses three of the four broad topics about which he repeatedly writes to his wife during the summers of 1862, 1863, and 1864: managing domestic affairs and sustaining familial bonds when family members are separated for long periods by great distances; the rhetoric and logistics of mid-nineteenth-century correspondence; and the economic, logistical, and physical challenges of the riverboat business, especially on a waterway as critical as the Ohio River in the midst of the American Civil War (in other letters, Anderson also reflects more broadly on the uncertainties, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime).

However, this letter is also unique. All but two of the letters were written from Cincinnati, a thriving center of commerce on the Ohio River approximately halfway between its source at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its confluence with the Mississippi River a mile or so south of Cairo, Illinois. The remaining letter in the collection was written from St. Louis, Missouri—though Anderson mentions writing from Louisville, Kentucky and Nashville, Tennessee as well. This letter was written from Pittsburgh, William and Louisa's home town. Presumably, he had been visiting his family and had expected to leave Pittsburgh by the Friday in late June when he wrote the letter; he writes to inform his wife of a delay.

As the collection in general reveals, delays were common, caused variously by negotiations over freight, water levels on the river, mechanical difficulties, and various military complications. Arrangements regarding freight seem to have kept Anderson in Pittsburgh overnight on June 27. He wants to secure a full load before leaving Pittsburgh because he "cannot depend upon getting any freight below here." He takes the opportunity to ask Louisa to send down "the Can of milk and 2 jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat." The definite article stands out: the Can of milk. One wonders whether, in his habitual haste (on which he often blames poor spelling and handwriting), he has simply rushed off and forgotten these items, and Louisa has sent him a note asking what she should do with them. In any case, in his haste to send her instructions, he crosses out the next two lines of his letter and recomposes them. Characteristically, the life of a riverboat captain seems frenetic.

It is also worth noting that he arranges to convey a note to his wife via "some one on the Shore at Shousetown." While the Andersons clearly handled much of their correspondence through the U.S. mail (he mentions post offices several times, and the collection includes one stamped envelope), they often convey both messages and goods through intermediaries traveling by rail or river.

Anderson's closing request constitutes something of a refrain in the letters. He asks Louisa to call on a Mr. Russell (probably John Russell, a local merchant) in order to collect money owed him, noting that he must meet his obligations on the crew's upcoming payday. Aside from suggesting that riverboat captains had to watch their cash flow carefully, this request reminds us that Louisa played a key role not only in caring for the Anderson household, including their four children (a fifth would be born in 1865), but also in tending to their business interests. Though we have only William Anderson's side of the correspondence, the letters reveal many details of Louisa's everyday life as well.

It is Louisa, presumably, whom we have to thank for initially preserving the letters, probably for the very common, personal reasons to which David Levy alludes in Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age: "In the privacy of our own homes we are likely to hold on to any number of treasures: cards, letters, and notes written long ago, photographs, scrapbooks filled with mementoes from an earlier era. We can't throw them out, even if we can't say why. We may look at them rarely or not at all, yet still it is somehow comforting to know they are there. It's as if something of importance is embedded in their very substance. This has less to do with their information content per se than with the emotions they evoke and the personal relationships they signify and embody" (96–97). The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University purchased the letters in part because they fit into a larger goal of acquiring materials that reveal the "common man's view of great events," and war letters are one focus of that larger effort (Smith). The collection as a whole, and the letter of 27 June 1862 more specifically, should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt). The passing of time has made the everyday information in the letters newly valuable, though the letters also retain the power Levy speaks of to evoke the emotional fabric of everyday life, especially when it becomes frayed in the course of great events.

projectDesc.p: This edition belongs to a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library (RBMS) at The Ohio State University Libraries. Other editions include "Selected Entries from the Lucius Clark Smith Diaries, 30 July 1862 to 31 December 1862"; "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868; "Journal of a Tour to Europe," by Samuel Sullivan Cox; and Louisa A. Doane's "Journal of Two Ocean Voyages (1852-1853)."

Each text was initially edited in connection with an undergraduate or graduate course on electronic textual editing offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses provided students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing served as each class's context for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provided a contact zone that helped students reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While the students' work focused on providing reliable textual editions, they also explored four threads inextricably woven into the work of electronic textual editing: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts; the history, characteristics, and preservation of physical and digital texts; the editorial processes and decisions that shape particular interpretations and presentations texts; and the mediation of electronic delivery systems.

These conceptual focuses, along with the time constraints of academic terms and the need to train students who had, typically, no prior experience in textual editing or the various technologies employed in electronic textual editing, strongly influenced the selection of texts in this series. Working with curators in the RBMS, Professor Ulman identified previously unpublished manuscript materials that were of potentially broad interest and that reflected a curatorial focus of the RBMS collection—for example, letters and personal diaries that connect private lives with larger historical contexts. Focusing on unique manuscript materials not, in all but one case, associated with other copies or later published versions also eliminated the need to compare multiple copies or states of the same work, perhaps held in other archives, an impractical task in the course of an academic term. Other practical matters also informed the choice of materials, including the possibility of scanning the source documents before the class so that students could work with both the original documents and high-resolutions facsimiles as they transcribed and encoded the source texts.

Thus, the editions in this series are documentary editions—interpretations and representations of single documents—designed to provide wider exposure and access to manuscript materials that might otherwise be overlooked, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Stephens edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical documents, the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the texts, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

Over the course of several years following the classes in which students worked on the editions, Professor Ulman revised the introductory materials to ensure stylistic consistency and proofed the transcription and encoding. He also redesigned the structure of the editions to meet the requirements of Ohio State's institutional repository, evolving accessibility standards, and feedback from peer reviewers. However, he did not undertake a complete retranscription of the source text or revision of the students' introductory essays and annotations.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality. All edges were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages..

Transcription. Editing of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription: abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underlining, additions above and below the line or in the margins, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed and encoded as they appear in the original manuscripts. The representation of those features varies depending on the view of the letter. An explanation of the presentation in each view of the letters can be read via the "About this View" link at the top of each view's page.

Markup and Annotation. XML encoding of the Anderson letters follows The Text Encoding Initiative's (TEI) P5: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, as customized for the project using the TEI's ODD ("One Document Does it All") process. This editorial introduction and the three "views" of the letters were generated from the main XML file using XSL transformations to produce HTML Web pages. Several of the appendices were encoded in HTML separately. A more detailed description of the markup can be found via the "Appendices" menu, and all source files (XML, XSL, CSS, ODD, RNC) can be viewed and downloaded via the "Source Files" menu.

Introductory material (such as this editorial introduction) as well as annotated lists of people, places, ships, and organizations mentioned in the letters are encoded in the TEI header of the main XML document. Other explanatory annotations are linked directly from the text. Separate appendices provide further information about the project (e.g., acknowledgements, editors' bios, and so on). All these ancillary materials can be viewed via the menus at the top of each page.

Proofing. Students who created the original transcriptions proofread their own transcription and encoding. In preparation for peer review by NINES and preservation in The Ohio State University's Knowledge Bank, the transcriptions and encoding were once again proofread by Professor Ulman.
Peer Review. Anonymous reviewers for NINES provided peer-reviews for the editions, in response to which they were revised and then reviewed by NINES editors before being listed in the NINES database.

Production and Archival Location of Digital Assets. All of the files associated with this edition are accessed via, and archived in, The Ohio State University's institutional repository, the Knowledge Bank.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 16 June 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Anderson writes home to Louisa from Cincinnati, Ohio. He is hauling Coal Boat men from Louisville, Kentucky. While in Cincinnati, Anderson visits his mother-in-law (whom he calls the "old lady") as well as family friends. During the dry, dusty, June weather, a fire breaks out near the Ohio River and Third St, destroying several houses. Anderson closes the letter by inviting Louisa to accompany him on his next trip to Cincinnati.

physDesc.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated June 16, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on two sides of a loose sheet of manilla-colored paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. The sheet appears to have been folded in half once. A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper left- hand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inch (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO" over an ornate shield topped by a crown.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 27 June 1862.
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Writing from Pittsburgh, Anderson tells Louisa that his boat's departure has been delayed by a day and asks her to send some food and clothes to him at the dock in Shousetown, PA. He also expresses anxiety about whether his trip will be profitable and asks his wife to request some money from a Mr. Russell to help cover an upcoming payday for his crew.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 11 July 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Anderson writes that he hopes his boat will beat riverboat Fanny McBurney to Maysville, KY in order to realize more profit on the trip, though he thinks his "prospects are poor" and is concerned about delays due to low water. He complains that his sleep has been restless because of mosquitoes, and he asks Louisa to write more—and at greater length—about their children and their crops.

msContents.p: In this letter, Anderson writes to his wife about his daily tasks and his hardships while being a riverboat captain. He reports that a shaft has broken on the boat, and hopes the new part will arrive soon. Anderson continues his letter and describes how he feels about boarding soldiers on his riverboat. His emotions of grief and sadness overrun the second half of his letter, and he explains that he feels terrible watching families be torn apart. Anderson closes with warm wishes to his family and that he hopes to hear from them soon.

msContents.p: In this document, William B. Anderson lists his itinerary and the business conducted at each port of call. He brings oats to Gallipolis, Ohio; retrieves wheat from Graham's Station, West Virginia, and brings it to Blennerhasset's Island, West Virginia. During his travels, it was necessary to build a chute and hire oxen in order to bring the wheat to Blennerhasset's Island. In the latter part of the letter, Anderson discusses his hope to sell his boat, as business is stopped now that the previous travels are finished. He finishes by sending his love to his wife and children.

titleStmt.title: A homesick letter to Mary Louisa Anderson written from Cincinnati on Sept. 17, 1862, by William B. Anderson
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Anderson shows a bit of emotion as he recounts his encounters with the war thus far. Anderson writes of the impoverished life he and his fellow shipmates live and becomes nostalgic over the simpler pleasures in life like butter and beef. Anderson asks his wife to pay a vist to John Russell in order to collect the money that Russell owes Anderson; Anderson fears that Russell will be slow to repay if his wife does not express a strong sense of need. Anderson closes the letter optimistically speaking of great times to come with his wife and children once he returns home.

physDesc.p: This letter in written on a single thin piece of blue-lined paper as the writing on the opposite side shows through. The singular, vertical jagged edge on the left side of the paper suggests that the paper was torn from a notebook or journal. The paper is approximately 8 x 9.75 inches in dimension. Anderson wrote the letter in brown ink and folded the letter three times( once crosswise and twice length-wise) to create six equally-sized sections so that the letter could fit into one of his standard envelopes. On the bottom of the first page, several words are smudged perhaps as a result of moisture on the captain's hand from the summer heat or from a rapid writing pace that did not allow the ink to dry sufficiently.

titleStmt.title: October 7, 1862 Letter from William B. Anderson Pertaining to Everyday Life During the Civil War

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Anderson reports hearing shooting along the river. He references two captains who were put in jail for cowardice. He expresses concern that he does not know what his orders will be from one day to the next. He speaks of a funeral of a friend's son in Maysville, and worries that his wife is sick or mad because he has not heard from her. This letter was written in October, making it one of the latest in the season, possibly indicating unseasonably warm weather or extenuating circumstances.

titleStmt.title: My Dear Wife: A Riverboat Captain's Missive to His Love
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: On June 19th, 1863, riverboat captain William B. Anderson penned a letter to his wife from St. Louis, Missouri, in which he informs his spouse of matters concerning river travel, his salary, and a bout of illness that left him bedridden.

physDesc.p: The single folded sheet, yellowed with age, has writing on both the front and back in black ink, as well as a printer's mark in the upper left hand corner. William B. Anderson's letter dated June 19th, 1863 from St. Louis, Missouri, is addressed to his wife Louisa and is written in ink on both sides of a loose sheet of off-white paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm). The paper is ruled with horizontal lines of a blue color that are spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) top margin that is unruled. The sheet's left edge is not a clean line like the remaining three, suggesting that it was most likely torn from a notepad of some sort. Written in black ink, the letter appears to have originally been folded once horizontally and twice vertically. A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper left corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge of the paper and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the exact origins of the mark is inconclusive, it resembles a similarly sized and placed printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, that reads: "MT HOLLY PAPER CO."

opener.note: June 19, 1863 fell on a Friday, not Saturday.

div.p:
I will commence a letter to you
this afternoon & Finish it tomorrow we arrived
here last night about Midnight we had
a fair trip around & if we get as good a one
back we will make a little money times are very
dull & and prices poor we had all the freight we could
carry on the water I have several small lots engaged
to go back to Louisville & CincinnatiCin. & I think by Monday
night we shall have all we can carry I had thought
somebody would be here and offer to buy the boat but
the Boat fervor has subsided greatly I had a visit
from Capt. R. C. Gray today & he says that he thinks that

than the St Louis and CincinnatiCin. trade but I dont wish to go up
there for the present. I had an offer at CincinnatiCin. to sell & I will
know what I can do when I return if the party accepts my
offer I will be home Shortly.

Sunday Evening I have been rather under the weather
since I left Louisville & had today to have a
Doctor & he gave me a lot of MedicineMedacin and as
Soon as I took of it got better he says I would
have had the ague or a bad attack of Billious
fever if I had not had relief soon I thought
it was the Neuralgia I had, for one side of
of my face & jaw pained me constantly
and my teeth ached & I had one of them
pulled and it did not do any good and
for 48 hours, I had not eaten one bite nor
slept one minute. I was not well one minute
at a time until I took the medicine and it
acted like a charm I am of course weak
but feel well and tomorrow I want to go
and see Belle Ferguson I have not been out
of my room nor in fact out of bed all
day till this Evening. I would not have
believed that a few doses of medicine would
do so much in so short a time. I will
send you a paper or two tomorrow I
hope you are well give my love to
the children excuse this poor letter
for I can assure you that I have had
better to say – I will leave here for
Cin Tomorrow night without I get
disappointed. I have been unable to go
up Town to see how it looks but will
Tomorrow if nothing happens & my
health improves I feelfeell sure I will
be all right again in a day or two

msContents.p: In this letter, from July 1, 1863, William B. Anderson writes to his wife, Mary Louisa, from Cincinnati. Anderson tells his wife about the Government cargo he is shipping, and the hard work that goes along with handling the cargo in the summer heat. Anderson also gives Mary Louisa advice pertaining to family and financial affairs back home in Pittsburgh. He ends the letter as he does most, with affection for his wife and telling her to kiss "the little ones" for him.

titleStmt.title: W.B. Anderson During The Burning of Lebanon During the Cival War
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter W.B. Anderson gives us a description of the difficulty he has unloading a shipment because of the civil war. More importantly though Anderson gives us an insight in this letter to the burning of Lebanon during the civil war, from the stand point of a civilian in public enterprise during this time. Some of the impact that we are given insight to includes the organization of local troops and how it is holding back Anderson and his shipment.

physDesc.p: This three page long letter written by W.B. Anderson on July fifth 1863 is written with a brown/black ink on a loose piece of off-white, blue lined paper, approximately 7.5inches wide by 10 inches long. The letter in its current state is appears as if it was folded twice vertically and once horizontally. The document was written front and back on 2 sheets of paper for a total of 3 pages in length. The page also contains a printer’s mark in the upper right hand corner of the page which is now indistinguishable. This printer’s mark closely resembles other printers marks found on several of Anderson’s letters including the letter of 27 June 1862 and the letter of 1 July 1863. On these other letters you can more clearly read "MT HOLLY PAPER CO."

msContents.p: Anderson informs his wife that the sickly Elias will bring her some money when he returns to Pittsburgh. Anderson then describes his current employment transporting goods for the government. He hopes to make enough money over the summer so that he can stay at home for the winter. While apologizing for an apparent scarcity of letters, Anderson claims that he has written frequently, and speculates that the Morgan raid may have interfered with mail delivery.

titleStmt.title: W. B. Anderson Letter--8/1/1863--A busy moment for family and business.
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Anderson shoots off a short letter announcing a dinner with his wife's mother and Ella (as yet an unknown relative or friend mentioned in several of Anderson's letters). He suggests that the boat (Glide II) will leave that afternoon from Cincinnati for Nashville with 200 mules aboard. He sends by Adams Express $3600 for business-related expenses (Adams Express was a very profitable delivery company started in the 1850s and had parallel systems of delivery in the south during the war (Pixley, 2002). and reminds his wife that he sent $60 for family expenses with the previous letter.

In this one-page, hurried letter to his wife--which followed a longer letter just the day before--Anderson suggests many things about the times and activities on the riverboat. He mentions the transport of animals (200 mules) along with personal commitments: Anderson met his wife's mother and Ella (an unknown relative or friend) on the boat (Glide II) and was about to leave for dinner. Before the afternoon departure, he was also intent upon sending business funds to his wife and money for family expenses: All this in one page on lined notebook paper with little punctuation and a postscript anticipating a subsequent letter from Nashville.

put it onboard the Boat today to Keep it safe
for fear of rain now I have to lay here with it in
the Boat till Tuesday & then I am to commence to
load again for Louisville I have a little better
prospect than before. I left you that PittsburghPittsbg
Money & put it in that Big Pocket Book I Took
the Gov money & Pd Mr Hamilton the 168$ to pay
the Taxes with. I have not seen the Old Lady
yet it has been Excessively hot today & has rained
a little & is Cloudy with prospects of rain. I have
been Tollerable well since I wrote last. I have
no news of any importance to write about
I would like you to send me one of Each
of the Likenesses of You & the children to look
at occasionally I may go below from
Louisville this trip if the Canal is open
though it is very uncertain

Direct your letters to me in Care
of Harry Davidson and co Cincinnati Ohio
instead of Barker Hart & Cook & I will
get them in the night as well as day
for they keep a man to sleep in the store
Kiss all the little ones and tell them
to be good

let me hear often from you & tell
me how the crops look &c. &c. get
a girl soon as you can & take
care of your own health & that of the
children

postscript.p:
P.S. I will drop you a line again
when I leave here
Yours William B. AndersonWBA
